com.intel.util.provider.sqlite

Class AbstractSqliteContentProvider

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.content.ContentProvider
      • com.intel.util.provider.sqlite.AbstractSqliteContentProvider
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.content.ComponentCallbacks2
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SqliteContentProviderImpl, StorageProvider

    @ThreadSafe
public abstract class AbstractSqliteContentProvider
extends android.content.ContentProvider
    Abstract superclass for SQLite-based ContentProviders.

    To use this class, clients need to implement three methods: getAppUriMatcher(), getSqliteOpenHelper(), and getBackupMonitor(). The objects returned by those methods encapsulate app-specific ContentProvider behavior.

    In addition to sending content change notifications, this class also automatically sends Intent.ACTION_PROVIDER_CHANGED.

                                    android.content.Context context,

        contentAuthority - Authority of the Content Provider.
        runnable - Runnable to execute.

      • backupDatabase

        @Slow(value=MILLISECONDS)
public static void backupDatabase(@NonNull
                                                            android.content.Context context,
                                                            @NonNull
                                                            java.lang.String contentAuthority,
                                                            @NonNull
                                                            java.lang.String savePath)
                                                     throws java.io.IOException
        Helper method for backing up the sqlite3 database.
        Parameters:
        context - The Android application context.
        contentAuthority - The authority of the content provider.
        savePath - An absolute path to the output file where the database should be copied to.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Thrown if the output file directories do not exist or if the database count not be copied.

      • runInTransaction

        public void runInTransaction(@NonNull
                             java.lang.Runnable runnable)
        Runs a block of code inside a single atomic transaction. For the most part, multiple operations should be performed using applyBatch(ArrayList). In certain cases where that isn't possible (for example, queries), this method can be used.

        The runnable must meet the following requirements:

        • The work done inside runnable should only be database operations to minimize the amount of time the database is blocked.
        Parameters:
        runnable - to execute inside the database transaction.

      • getAppUriMatcher

        @NonNull
protected abstract AppUriMatcher getAppUriMatcher()
        Returns:
        An AppUriMatcher appropriate for the current ContentProvider. The object returned by this method must be thread-safe.

      • getSqliteOpenHelper

        @NonNull
protected abstract android.database.sqlite.SQLiteOpenHelper getSqliteOpenHelper()
        Returns:
        A SQLiteOpenHelper appropriate for the current ContentProvider. The object returned by this method must be thread-safe.

      • getBackupMonitor

        @Nullable
protected abstract ContentProviderBackupMonitor getBackupMonitor()
        Returns:
        An optional ContentProviderBackupMonitor appropriate for the current ContentProvider. The object returned by this method must be thread-safe.
